steps.title: Check for signs of an overdose.
steps.content: Check for signs of an overdose. Before you administer Narcan, make sure to check the person for symptoms of an overdose. Symptoms may include: [2] X Research source Slow or shallow breathing. Gasping noises while sleeping or snoring in an unusual way. Skin that is pale or bluish. A slow heartbeat. Low blood pressure. Unresponsive and will not wake up.

steps.title: Call emergency services
steps.content: Call emergency services . Call 911 or emergency services in your country right away! It is important to ensure that help is on the way before you do anything. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Check the person's airway and administer rescue breaths.
steps.content: Check the person's airway and administer rescue breaths . Check the person's mouth and throat to ensure that there is nothing blocking their airways. Place one hand on the person's chin, tilt up their head slightly, and pinch their nose closed. Then, make a seal around their mouth with your mouth, breathe in and blow the breath into their mouth. You should see their chest rise as you deliver the rescue breath and then fall as you remove your mouth from their mouth. [4] X Research source Deliver one breath every five seconds.

steps.title: Remove the yellow caps from the syringe.
steps.content: Remove the yellow caps from the syringe. Prepare the nasal syringe immediately after giving several rescue breaths (if necessary). Pry or pull off the yellow caps. There are usually two – one at each end of the syringe. A syringe is not a needle, it's a plastic device that holds the needle – or in this case, what the Narcan screws onto. You can find Narcan through the getnaloxonenow.org website.

steps.title: Take the red cap off the Narcan.
steps.content: Take the red cap off the Narcan. The tube of Narcan (also labeled under the generic name naloxone) may have a red cap. Pry this off and discard it.

steps.title: Put the three pieces together.
steps.content: Put the three pieces together. Grip the clear plastic wings of the nasal atomizer (the cone-shaped applicator), and insert it onto the syringe. Gently screw the Narcan container onto the barrel of the syringe. Do not prime or test the spray. It is single-use and can't be reused. [5] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Some Narcan nasal sprays come in single-use, pre-assembled packages. They contain two needle-free devices, one to use in each nostril.

steps.title: Administer the Narcan half in each nostril.
steps.content: Administer the Narcan half in each nostril. Lay the victim on their back and tilt their head back. Place the white cone applicator into one nostril of the victim's nose. Give a short, hard push onto the end of the capsule to spray the Narcan. Deliver half of the container (1cc). Repeat the process immediately in the victim's other nostril.

steps.title: Remove the outer case.
steps.content: Remove the outer case. Injectable Narcan, labeled as EVZIO, comes in a case. Take the device out of the case, but do not remove the red safety guard until you are ready to inject the medicine.

steps.title: Take off the red safety guard.
steps.content: Take off the red safety guard. When you are ready to inject, remove the red safety guard. You might need to pull the red safety guard a little hard to get it off. Do not touch the black area of the EZVIO after you get the red safety tab off. This is where the needle is located.

steps.title: Place the black end of the device against the outer thigh and inject.
steps.content: Place the black end of the device against the outer thigh and inject. Place the black area of the device on the middle of the person's outer thigh so that it is right over the muscle. To inject the medicine, hold the device firmly against the person's thigh for five seconds. You do not need to remove the person's clothing to do this. You will hear a click and hiss sound as the device automatically injects the medicine into the person's thigh. This is normal and means the device is working. The needle will retract into the device after the injection is complete.

steps.title: Call emergency services
steps.content: Call emergency services . Make sure to call 911 (or emergency services in your country) immediately after giving the injection or have someone call for help while you are giving the injection.

steps.title: Administer Narcan only if the victim meets the criteria.
steps.content: Administer Narcan only if the victim meets the criteria. Only administer Narcan if the victim exhibits the following signs of overdose: They are unconscious, unresponsive, and you cannot wake them They have pinpoint (constricted) pupils Their breathing is slow and shallow, breathing fewer than 8 times per minute

steps.title: Provide supportive care until help arrives.
steps.content: Provide supportive care until help arrives. When you find a loved one unconscious, yell and rub your knuckles on the center of their breastbone to try to wake them. If they wake up, they do not need Narcan. [6] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source If not, call emergency services immediately and tell them that someone may have overdosed. Before giving Narcan, see if the victim needs CPR - this may save their life! Follow these guidelines: Count their breaths: Listening at their mouth while watching to see whether their chest is rising and falling for 5-10 seconds. [7] X Research source If they are not breathing or are breathing fewer than 8 times per minute, give them a few rescue breaths before administering Narcan. Check for a pulse for 30 seconds by placing your middle and forefingers on the victim's neck just off to the side a little, under the jaw line. If they don't have a pulse, start CPR chest compressions.

steps.title: Be sure the victim gets to the hospital.
steps.content: Be sure the victim gets to the hospital. Emergency services should immediately take the victim to intensive care for monitoring. If you are unable to access emergency services, get the person to the hospital as soon as they can breathe on their own. They need medical care even if their overdose is reversed by Narcan.

steps.title: Encourage the victim not to use again that day.
steps.content: Encourage the victim not to use again that day. Narcan can cause symptoms of withdrawal, making the victim want to use their drug again. Doing so can cause another overdose. These cravings may be difficult for both of you to deal with. Try to support the victim emotionally, and encourage them not to use drugs again that day.

steps.title: Store the Narcan appropriately.
steps.content: Store the Narcan appropriately. Store any Narcan you have tightly closed in its original container and out of the reach of children. [8] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Store it at room temperature in a dark place and avoid keeping it anywhere that gets hot or moist, such as in the bathroom. Never freeze the medicine either. [9] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Dispose of the Narcan and get a new one if the red safety guard has been removed, it is expired, it looks cloudy or you can see particles floating in it. Keep it safely out of reach of children. Do not let anyone else use your medication.

steps.title: Know the victim's drug of abuse.
steps.content: Know the victim's drug of abuse. If a loved one uses illegal drugs or takes prescription medications inappropriately, try to find out what they take. Ask them outright and let them know you're concerned about their safety. Narcan can reverse the effects of opiate drugs such as: Heroin Prescription pain medicine like fentanyl, morphine, methadone, buprenorphine, hydrocodone, and oxycodone Some common brand name medications such as Percocet, OxyContin, Vicodin, Percodan, Tylox, and Demerol

steps.title: Get Narcan from a doctor.
steps.content: Get Narcan from a doctor. If you or a loved one suffer from opiate addiction, talk to your doctor about getting Narcan to keep on hand. You may be able to obtain liquid Narcan that can be injected into a vein, muscle, or under the skin, or a nasal spray. You need a prescription to get Narcan in some states but not others. Automatic injection devices (Evzio) are sometimes available. These have voice guidance that can direct you or another on how to use the device. Use it once then throw it away. This is the BEST OPTION if you do not have medical training. You will probably not be able to administer Narcan to yourself if you are overdosing. Friends, family, and loved ones should know how to use the Narcan and where to find it.

steps.title: Do a quick scan for signs of opiate overdose.
steps.content: Do a quick scan for signs of opiate overdose. You may not always know what drug someone has overdosed on, or if they've used drugs at all. Don't waste time, but look very quickly for some signs that the victim may have overdosed on opiates. Scan quickly for prescription drug bottles lying around, a morphine or fentanyl patch on their body (remove it!) or visible drug paraphernalia like syringes, spoons, and tourniquets.
